Show HN: I'm building an email service on the blockchain
text:
Hey HN! I'm a UG university student, and I'm building an email service built on the Solana blockchain.

Companies like Google have way too much control over email. They get to decide whether or not mail hits your inbox. I've had incidents in the past where Gmail silently blocked my emails because their AI thought they were malicious.

You may say "use your own mail server", but that is easier said than done; the average user has neither time nor skill. Besides, if your contacts are using Gmail, good luck getting past their spam filter on a shared IP.

On the more philosophical side, services like Gmail and Outlook give the illusion that their services are free to use, which leads to over-consumption and over-reliance. At the end of the day somebody has to pay the bills - why not let the user pay for what they use instead of absorbing that cost and selling their data?

--

On the technical side of things, it uses decentralized technologies like IPFS to store your emails. There is absolutely no centralized server involved (unless you consider our web host, Netlify) and you will soon be able to run the webapp locally.

What about encryption, you say? We currently encrypt all email content, including subject and attachments using x25519-xsalsa20-poly1305, via the libsodium box API. Before the stable release we will switch to a post-quantum encryption scheme such as NTRU.

Thanks for reading till the end!

PS: The service is hosted at https://stenzor.com

Ask HN: How to Start with HN?
text:
After a several month of regularly reading the top HN post, I decided to finally create an account and post my own awesome link to HN. However, it seems like the post new made it public. It is still listed under my submissions, but when I am not logged in, I cannot find the post. I now read several articles, explaining the karma system, guidelines and strategies someone can use to push your post, but it is still quite confusing (i.e. Karma is connected to the success of your posts. But what does "post" actually mean? Does this also include comments? What are the main thinks I need to know before I start posting to HN?). 
So many questions and nobody I know, who I could ask. Maybe the community can help me?

title: A Cost-Effective Way of Using the Modern Data Stack(II)
Show HN: I built a 3rd-party status page for GitHub on Cloudflare Pages
text:
For the curious: It's a Remix app running on Cloudflare Pages, with a plain old Node/Express API and postgres db.

The uptime data comes from OnlineOrNot.com, though I'll be integrating Pingdom and a few other uptime monitoring services later. Once the uptime monitoring detects an outage, the status page automatically updates, and sends emails to anyone subscribed.

I used Remix because I wanted to write React components with Tailwind CSS, but have them "compile down" to just HTML/CSS. The output HTML/CSS is around 10.1KiB in total.

Show HN: I spent a year designing a low profile, minimal mechanical keyboard
text:
Hi HN,

During lockdown I took up the keyboard hobby but I couldn't find anything I liked the aesthetic of. So I set out to design my own keyboard from scratch that shunned the gamer look in favour of a more minimal, serious design.

I've built several prototypes but I would love to get some feedback from the HN community.

Ask HN: How do I disable middle-click paste in Chrome?
text:
Let me start by apologising for asking this here. I suspect it isn't entirely in the spirit of typical HN discussion. It's just that I cannot find the solution elsewhere online despite my best efforts. Perhaps I'm growing incompetent in my old age. On Ubuntu (20.04), you can use gnome-tweaks to disable the middle-click-to-paste feature. Once disabled here, it is applied to all gnome apps and assorted programs (for example the text editor, terminal, etc.).

However for some reason the middle-click-paste persists inside of Chrome. This is extremely frustrating because I am one of those users that likes to hold down middle-click to scroll (which is particularly ergonomic on my ThinkPad - fellow ThinkPad users will understand).

What's happening now however is that whenever I scroll in Chrome whilst typing an email or filling in forms it just randomly pastes whatever is in my clipboard. Aside from being annoying, I've on occasion also accidentally submitted / sent erroneously pasted text.

How on earth can I disable middle-click-paste in Chrome without disabling middle-click altogether?

Is there some kind of Chrome setting or flag or extension?

Help me HNers; you're my only hope.
